name: OGLE-2005-BLG-390L
scenarioDescription:
The OGLE-2005-BLG-390L Exoplanetary System

OGLE-2005-BLG-390L is a star with 0.22 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.283 times its radius. It is located 21526.30 light years away from the solar system.

OGLE-2005-BLG-390L is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

OGLE-2005-BLG-390L b

OGLE-2005-BLG-390L b was discovered by the OGLE observatory using the microlensing method. Its discovery was announced in 2006-01. Its semi-major axis is 2.60 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3285.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, OGLE-2005-BLG-390L.

The mass of OGLE-2005-BLG-390L b is 5.40 times the mass of Earth. At 5.40 Earth masses, OGLE-2005-BLG-390L b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system OGLE-2005-BLG-390L, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by OGLE.
